canonical_explanation.text: Spherical mirrors are curved mirrors that form part of a sphere. There are two types: concave mirrors (reflecting surface curves inward) and convex mirrors (reflecting surface curves outward). Key terms include pole (P) - center of mirror surface, center of curvature (C) - center of the sphere, radius of curvature (R), principal axis, principal focus (F), and focal length (f). For spherical mirrors, R = 2f. Concave mirrors can form real or virtual images depending on object position, while convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images. Concave mirrors are used in shaving mirrors and torches, while convex mirrors are used in vehicle rear-view mirrors.
rules: Concave mirror: reflecting surface curves inward.
Convex mirror: reflecting surface curves outward.
Radius of curvature R = 2 × focal length (R = 2f)
Concave mirrors can form real or virtual images.
Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, diminished images.
Focus of concave mirror is in front (real focus).
Focus of convex mirror is behind (virtual focus).
Uses of concave: shaving mirrors, dentist mirrors, torches.
Uses of convex: vehicle rear-view mirrors, shop security mirrors.

questions.question_text: A mirror whose reflecting surface curves inward is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A mirror whose reflecting surface curves inward is called a concave mirror. This is because the curved surface of the mirror reflects light inward, towards the center of the curvature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex mirror is one whose reflecting surface curves outward, like the outside of a sphere. The correct answer is a concave mirror, which curves inward like the inside of a sphere. Concave mirrors can form real or virtual images depending on the position of the object, while convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images.

questions.question_text: A mirror whose reflecting surface curves outward is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A mirror whose reflecting surface curves outward is called a convex mirror. This is because the curved surface bulges out, forming the shape of a sphere's outer surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror has a reflecting surface that curves inward, forming a bowl-like shape. A plane mirror has a flat, even reflecting surface. A spherical mirror can be either concave or convex, depending on whether the surface curves inward or outward. Therefore, the correct answer is that a mirror whose reflecting surface curves outward is called a convex mirror.

questions.question_text: The center point of the spherical mirror surface is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The center point of the spherical mirror surface is called the pole (P) because it is the point at the center of the mirror where the reflecting surface curves inward (for concave mirrors) or outward (for convex mirrors).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The center of curvature (C) is the center of the sphere that the mirror is a part of, not the center of the mirror surface itself. The focus (F) is the point where light rays parallel to the principal axis converge after reflecting off the mirror. The vertex is the point where the principal axis meets the mirror surface, which is not the same as the pole (P).

questions.question_text: The relationship between radius of curvature (R) and focal length (f) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct relationship between the radius of curvature (R) and the focal length (f) of a spherical mirror is R = 2f. This is because the focal length of a spherical mirror is half the radius of curvature, as the mirror forms part of a sphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct option is B) R = 2f. This is because the focal length of a spherical mirror is related to its radius of curvature by the formula f = R/2. Therefore, the radius of curvature is twice the focal length, or R = 2f. The other options, such as R = f, R = f/2, or R = 3f, are not correct relationships between these two important properties of spherical mirrors.

questions.question_text: Images formed by convex mirrors are always:
questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images. This is because convex mirrors have a diverging effect on light rays, causing them to spread out instead of converging. The image formed is behind the mirror, smaller than the object, and upright.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors do not form real, inverted images. This is because real images can only be formed by concave mirrors when the object is placed between the principal focus and the center of curvature. Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images, which means the image appears behind the mirror, is upright, and smaller than the object.

questions.question_text: Which mirror is used as a shaving mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror is used as a shaving mirror because it can form a magnified, virtual image of the user's face, allowing them to see their features clearly while shaving. Concave mirrors have a curved reflecting surface that bends light inward, making objects appear larger and closer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are not used as shaving mirrors because they form a diminished, virtual image that makes objects appear smaller and farther away. Plane mirrors and cylindrical mirrors are also not commonly used as shaving mirrors. Concave mirrors are the best choice for shaving mirrors because they can provide a magnified view of the user's face.

questions.question_text: Rear-view mirrors in vehicles are usually:
questions.explanation_correct: Rear-view mirrors in vehicles are usually convex mirrors because convex mirrors have a curved outward surface that can provide a wider field of view to the driver. This helps the driver see more of the area behind the vehicle, which is important for safe driving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rear-view mirrors are not concave mirrors because concave mirrors have a curved inward surface that makes objects appear closer than they actually are. This would not be useful for a rear-view mirror, as the driver needs to see a wider view of the area behind the vehicle. Rear-view mirrors are also not plane mirrors or colored mirrors, as these would not provide the same wide field of view that a convex mirror can.

questions.question_text: When an object is placed between the pole and focus of a concave mirror, the image formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed between the pole and focus of a concave mirror, the image formed is virtual, erect, and magnified. This is because the light rays diverge after reflecting off the concave mirror, creating a virtual image that is larger than the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because concave mirrors can form virtual, erect, and magnified images when the object is placed between the pole and focus. The other options are incorrect - option A describes a real and inverted image, option C describes a virtual and diminished image, and option D describes a real and magnified image, which are not the case when the object is placed in this position relative to the concave mirror.

questions.question_text: An object is placed at the center of curvature of a concave mirror. The image is:

options.text: At the center of curvature, same size, real, inverted
Between focus and center of curvature

questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at the center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, the image is formed at the center of curvature, same size, real, and inverted. This is because the rays from the object travel to the mirror surface and reflect back to the center of curvature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) The image is not at infinity, as the object is placed at the center of curvature. C) The image is not between the focus and center of curvature, as the object is at the center of curvature. D) The image is not virtual and erect, as the image formed is real and inverted.

questions.question_text: If the focal length of a concave mirror is 15 cm, its radius of curvature is:
questions.explanation_correct: The focal length (f) of a concave mirror is related to its radius of curvature (R) by the formula R = 2f. Since the focal length is given as 15 cm, the radius of curvature can be calculated as R = 2 × 15 cm = 30 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (7.5 cm) is incorrect because the radius of curvature is not half the focal length. Option B (15 cm) is incorrect because the radius of curvature is not equal to the focal length. Option D (45 cm) is incorrect because the radius of curvature is not three times the focal length. The correct option is C (30 cm), which is calculated using the formula R = 2f.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curving outward.
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curving inward, not outward. The reflecting surface of a concave mirror is the inner curved surface, which means it reflects light inward towards the center of the sphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curving inward, not outward. This means the mirror is curved like the inside of a sphere. The opposite of a concave mirror is a convex mirror, which has its reflecting surface curving outward like the outside of a sphere.

questions.question_text: Convex mirrors can form both real and virtual images.
questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors can only form virtual, erect, and diminished images, regardless of the position of the object. This is because the reflecting surface of a convex mirror curves outwards, causing the light rays to diverge and form a virtual image behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because convex mirrors cannot form real images. Convex mirrors always form virtual images, which means the image appears behind the mirror and cannot be projected onto a screen. This is due to the outwardly curved reflecting surface of the convex mirror, which causes the light rays to diverge and form a virtual image.

questions.question_text: Dentists use concave mirrors to see a magnified image of teeth.
questions.explanation_correct: Dentists use concave mirrors to see a magnified image of teeth. Concave mirrors can form real and magnified images of objects placed between the principal focus and the center of curvature of the mirror, which is why they are useful for dentists to closely examine teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dentists do not use convex mirrors to see teeth. Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images, which would not be suitable for dentists to closely examine teeth. Concave mirrors are the type of spherical mirrors that can form real and magnified images, making them the more appropriate choice for dentists.

questions.question_text: The focal length of a spherical mirror is half of its radius of curvature.
questions.explanation_correct: The focal length (f) of a spherical mirror is half of its radius of curvature (R). This is because the formula for a spherical mirror is R = 2f, so f = R/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is not true. The focal length (f) of a spherical mirror is not half of its radius of curvature (R). Instead, the relationship between them is R = 2f, meaning the radius of curvature is twice the focal length. So, the focal length is actually equal to half the radius of curvature.

questions.question_text: A mirror with its reflecting surface curving inward is called a ___ mirror.
questions.explanation_correct: A mirror with its reflecting surface curving inward is called a concave mirror. This is because the curve of the mirror surface is directed inward, towards the light rays that are reflected off it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'concave'. A mirror with its reflecting surface curving outward is called a convex mirror. Convex mirrors have a reflecting surface that curves outwards, away from the light rays that are reflected off it. Therefore, the correct answer is 'concave', not 'convex'.

questions.question_text: The point where parallel rays meet after reflection from a concave mirror is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The point where parallel rays meet after reflection from a concave mirror is called the focus. This is because the concave shape of the mirror causes the parallel rays to converge at a single point after reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'focus'. The focus is the point where parallel rays meet after reflection from a concave mirror. This is because the curved shape of the concave mirror bends the rays inwards, causing them to converge at a single point on the other side of the mirror.

questions.question_text: ___ mirrors are used in vehicle rear-view mirrors because they give a wider field of view.
questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors are used in vehicle rear-view mirrors because they give a wider field of view. This is because convex mirrors have a curved outward surface, which causes objects to appear smaller but allows you to see more of the area behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Convex'. Concave mirrors are not used in vehicle rear-view mirrors because they make objects appear larger and closer than they actually are, which can be misleading for the driver. Convex mirrors, on the other hand, make objects appear smaller and give a wider view of the area behind the vehicle, which is more useful for driving.

questions.question_text: The straight line passing through the pole and center of curvature is called the ___ axis.
questions.explanation_correct: The straight line passing through the pole (center of the mirror surface) and the center of curvature (center of the sphere) is called the principal axis because it is the main axis around which the mirror is designed and functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'principal'. The principal axis is the straight line passing through the pole and the center of curvature of the spherical mirror. This is the main axis that defines how the mirror works and forms images. Other terms like 'secondary' or 'auxiliary' would not be correct in this case.

questions.question_text: Arrange these points on a concave mirror from mirror surface outward:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from the mirror surface outward is Pole (P), Focus (F), Center of curvature (C). This is because the pole is the center of the mirror surface, the focus is the point where parallel rays converge, and the center of curvature is the center of the sphere that the mirror is part of.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Center of curvature (C), Pole (P), Focus (F). This is not correct because the center of curvature is the farthest point from the mirror surface, while the pole is the closest point on the mirror and the focus is in between the pole and the center of curvature.

questions.question_text: As an object moves from infinity towards a concave mirror, arrange the image positions:
questions.explanation_correct: As an object moves from infinity towards a concave mirror, the image position changes from being at infinity, to between the focus (F) and center of curvature (C), to exactly at the focus (F). This is because the light rays from the object become more and more converged as the object gets closer to the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the object is moved from infinity towards a concave mirror, the image position does not go from being at infinity to between F and C to at F. Instead, the image first appears at infinity, then moves to between F and C, and finally reaches the focus (F) when the object is very close to the mirror. This is because the light rays from the object become more converged as the object gets closer to the mirror.

questions.question_text: The center of the sphere of which the spherical mirror is a part is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The center of the sphere of which the spherical mirror is a part is called the center of curvature (C). This is because the mirror's curved reflecting surface is part of the larger sphere, and the center of this sphere is the center of curvature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pole (P) is the center of the mirror's curved surface, not the center of the sphere that the mirror is part of. The focus (F) is the point where light rays reflected from the mirror meet, and the principal axis is the imaginary line passing through the pole and the center of curvature. The correct answer is the center of curvature (C), which is the center of the sphere of which the spherical mirror is a part.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror is also called:
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror is called a converging mirror because it bends light rays inwards, allowing them to meet at a point called the focus. This makes it a 'converging' mirror, unlike a diverging or flat mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror is not called a diverging mirror, as diverging mirrors are actually convex mirrors that bend light rays outwards. A flat mirror or plane mirror is a mirror with a flat surface that reflects light without bending it. The correct term for a concave mirror is a 'converging mirror' because it converges or focuses light rays.

questions.question_text: A convex mirror is also called:
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror is called a diverging mirror because it causes light rays to spread out or diverge from the mirror's surface, forming a virtual, erect, and diminished image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex mirror is not a converging mirror, as it does not have the ability to focus light rays to a single point. It is also not a focusing mirror, as it does not bring light rays together. Finally, a convex mirror is not a plane mirror, as it has a curved reflecting surface rather than a flat one.

questions.question_text: A real image is one that:

options.text: Can be obtained on a screen

questions.explanation_correct: A real image is one that can be obtained on a screen or surface, as opposed to a virtual image which cannot be projected. This is because a real image is formed by the actual convergence of light rays, while a virtual image is formed by the divergence of light rays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A real image is not one that cannot be seen - a real image can be viewed directly or projected onto a screen. Real images are not always magnified, as they can also be diminished in size. And a real image is not always erect (upright) - it can also be inverted (upside down) depending on the position of the object relative to the mirror.

questions.question_text: The aperture of a spherical mirror is:

options.text: The diameter of the reflecting surface
The distance between pole and focus

questions.explanation_correct: The aperture of a spherical mirror is the diameter of the reflecting surface, which is the B) option. The aperture is the size or width of the mirror, not any of the other measurements like the focal length, radius of curvature, or distance between the pole and focus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The aperture is not the A) focal length, C) radius of curvature, or D) distance between the pole and focus. These are other important properties of the spherical mirror, but they do not directly define the size or width of the reflecting surface, which is what the aperture refers to.

questions.question_text: The focus of a convex mirror is:
questions.explanation_correct: The focus of a convex mirror is behind the mirror, which means it is a virtual focus. This is because convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images, regardless of the position of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The focus of a convex mirror is not in front of the mirror (real), at infinity, or at the pole. A convex mirror always forms a virtual focus behind the mirror. This is because the reflecting surface curves outward, which causes the light rays to diverge and appear to come from a point behind the mirror, creating a virtual focus.

questions.question_text: An object at focus of a concave mirror produces an image at:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at the focus of a concave mirror, the image is formed at infinity. This is because the rays of light from the object are parallel to the principal axis after reflection, creating an image that appears infinitely far away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the image would not be formed at the focus, as the object is already placed there. Option B is incorrect because the image would not be formed at the center of curvature, as the object is not placed there. Option D is incorrect because the image is not formed behind the mirror, but rather at infinity.

questions.question_text: Searchlights and headlights of vehicles use:

options.text: Concave mirrors with bulb at focus

questions.explanation_correct: Concave mirrors with the bulb placed at the principal focus are used in searchlights and vehicle headlights. This is because the concave mirror reflects the light rays from the bulb in parallel beams, creating a bright and focused beam of light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are not used in searchlights or vehicle headlights because they diverge the light rays, making the beam less focused. Plane mirrors and colored mirrors are also not suitable for these applications as they do not concentrate the light in the same way as a concave mirror with the bulb at the focus.

questions.question_text: An object placed beyond C of a concave mirror forms an image that is:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed beyond the center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, the image formed is diminished (smaller than the object), real (can be projected on a screen), and inverted (upside down) compared to the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because when an object is placed beyond C, the image is diminished, not enlarged. Option C is incorrect because the image is not the same size as the object, it is smaller. Option D is incorrect because the image is real, not virtual, and it is diminished, not magnified.

questions.question_text: Solar furnaces use:
questions.explanation_correct: Large concave mirrors (C) are used in solar furnaces because they can focus the sun's rays and produce a very high temperature at the focal point, which is essential for solar energy applications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solar furnaces do not use convex mirrors (A) because convex mirrors spread out the sun's rays instead of focusing them. Plane mirrors (B) and prisms (D) are not suitable for solar furnaces as they cannot concentrate the sun's energy effectively to produce the high temperatures required.

questions.question_text: A ray of light parallel to the principal axis, after reflection from a concave mirror:

options.text: Passes through the center of curvature
Goes back along the same path

questions.explanation_correct: A ray of light parallel to the principal axis of a concave mirror will reflect and pass through the focus (F) of the mirror. This is because the focal point (F) is where parallel rays converge after reflecting off the concave surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) The ray does not pass through the pole (P), which is the center of the mirror surface. C) The ray does not pass through the center of curvature (C), which is the center of the sphere that the mirror is a part of. D) The ray does not go back along the same path, but instead reflects and converges at the focal point (F).

questions.question_text: Why do convex mirrors give a wider field of view?

options.text: They form diminished images of distant objects

questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors form diminished images of distant objects, which allows them to show a wider field of view. This is because the curved surface of the convex mirror reflects light from a larger area, capturing more of the scene in front of it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are not larger or more reflective than other mirrors. They are curved outwards, which is why they form diminished images of distant objects. This wider field of view is useful for rear-view mirrors in vehicles, allowing the driver to see more of the area behind the car.

questions.question_text: An object is placed at infinity in front of a concave mirror. The image is formed at:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at infinity in front of a concave mirror, the light rays from the object reach the mirror parallel to the principal axis. These parallel rays are then reflected and converge at the focal point (F) of the mirror, which is the correct answer (C).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) The image is not formed at infinity, as the object is at infinity and the image is formed at the focal point. B) The center of curvature (C) is not the location of the image formation. D) The pole (P) is not the location of the image formation.

questions.question_text: The radius of curvature of a plane mirror is:
questions.explanation_correct: The radius of curvature of a plane mirror is infinite. This is because a plane mirror has a flat surface, not a curved one, so the center of curvature is infinitely far away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radius of curvature of a plane mirror is not zero, finite, or negative. A plane mirror has a flat surface, so it has no curvature. The correct answer is that the radius of curvature is infinite, meaning the center of curvature is infinitely far away from the mirror's surface.

questions.question_text: For a concave mirror, if the object is between F and C, the image is:
questions.explanation_correct: When the object is placed between the focus (F) and the center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, the image formed is real, inverted, and magnified, which corresponds to option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the object is placed between the focus (F) and the center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, the image will not be diminished (option A) or virtual and erect (option D). The correct option is B, where the image is real, inverted, and magnified, as the concave mirror converges the light rays from the object and forms the image beyond the center of curvature (C).

questions.question_text: A ray passing through the center of curvature of a concave mirror after reflection:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C. A ray passing through the center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror will retrace its path after reflection. This is because the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection for this ray, causing it to go back along the same path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C, not A, B, or D. If the ray passes through the center of curvature (C), it will retrace its path after reflection. It does not pass through the focus (F) or get parallel to the principal axis. The ray also does not get absorbed, as the surface of a concave mirror reflects the incident light.

questions.question_text: Which type of mirror is used in a torch?
questions.explanation_correct: Concave mirrors are used in torches because they can focus the light rays from the bulb into a narrow, bright beam. This is because the curved surface of a concave mirror acts like a lens to converge the light rays, making them more intense and directional.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are not used in torches because they cannot focus the light rays into a narrow beam. Instead, they cause the light rays to spread out, making the light less intense and more diffused. Plane mirrors also do not work well in torches, as they simply reflect the light without focusing it. Torches need a concave mirror to effectively concentrate the light and produce a bright, directional beam.

questions.question_text: ATM machines have which type of mirror above the keypad?
questions.explanation_correct: ATM machines use a convex mirror above the keypad because convex mirrors are curved outwards and can show a wide field of view. This allows the user to see a wider area behind them, which helps with security and safety while using the ATM.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ATM machines do not use a concave mirror above the keypad. Concave mirrors are curved inwards and can only show a smaller field of view, which would not be as useful for security purposes. Plane mirrors also do not provide the same wide viewing angle as a convex mirror.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is:
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms a virtual, erect, and same-size image of the object. This is because the image is formed behind the mirror at the same distance from the mirror as the object, but flipped horizontally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image formed by a plane mirror is not real and inverted, as in option A. Nor is it virtual and diminished, as in option C. And it is not real and magnified, as in option D. A plane mirror always forms a virtual, erect, and same-size image, which is why option B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: If the radius of curvature of a mirror is 40 cm, its focal length is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 20 cm. This is because the formula for the focal length (f) of a spherical mirror is f = R/2, where R is the radius of curvature. If the radius of curvature is 40 cm, then the focal length is 40 cm/2 = 20 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not follow the formula for focal length. A) 80 cm is incorrect because the focal length is half the radius of curvature, not the same as the radius of curvature. B) 40 cm is incorrect because it is the same as the radius of curvature, not half of it. D) 10 cm is incorrect because it is not the correct calculation using the given radius of curvature.

questions.question_text: A convex mirror can form real images.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image. This means that the image formed by a convex mirror is not real, but rather a virtual image that appears to be behind the mirror. The image is upright (erect) and smaller (diminished) than the actual object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that convex mirrors can form real images. However, this is not the case. Convex mirrors always form virtual images, meaning the image you see does not actually exist in front of the mirror. The image is a reflection that appears behind the mirror's surface. Real images can only be formed by concave mirrors, under certain conditions.

questions.question_text: The pole is the geometric center of the spherical mirror.
questions.explanation_correct: The pole is the geometric center of the spherical mirror. This is because the pole is the point on the mirror surface that is closest to the center of the sphere, which is the center of curvature (C) of the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The pole (P) is the geometric center of the spherical mirror, not the center of curvature (C). The center of curvature (C) is the center of the sphere of which the mirror forms a part, and it is located behind the mirror. The pole (P) is the point on the mirror surface that is closest to the center of curvature (C).

questions.question_text: A concave mirror always forms a magnified image.
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror does not always form a magnified image. The type of image formed by a concave mirror depends on the position of the object with respect to the mirror. If the object is placed between the pole (P) and the principal focus (F) of the mirror, the image formed will be virtual, erect, and magnified. However, if the object is placed beyond the center of curvature (C), the image formed will be real, inverted, and diminished.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. A concave mirror can form both magnified and diminished images, depending on the position of the object. If the object is placed between the pole (P) and the principal focus (F) of the mirror, the image will be magnified. But if the object is placed beyond the center of curvature (C), the image will be diminished. So a concave mirror does not always form a magnified image.

questions.question_text: Convex mirrors are preferred for rear-view mirrors because they give erect images with wider view.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is correct because convex mirrors give a wider field of view and form an erect, diminished image. This is ideal for rear-view mirrors in vehicles, allowing the driver to see more of the area behind the car.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because while convex mirrors do form erect images, the images are not wider. Convex mirrors actually provide a wider field of view compared to flat mirrors, but the images appear smaller (diminished). This wider view is the key reason why convex mirrors are preferred for rear-view mirrors in vehicles.

questions.question_text: The principal axis passes through the pole and the center of curvature.
questions.explanation_correct: The principal axis of a spherical mirror passes through the pole (P) and the center of curvature (C) of the mirror. This is because the principal axis is the line that passes through the center of the sphere of which the mirror is a part.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The principal axis of a spherical mirror is the straight line that passes through the pole (P) and the center of curvature (C) of the mirror. This is because the principal axis is the line that is perpendicular to the surface of the mirror at the pole.

questions.question_text: Inverted images can be real or virtual.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Concave mirrors can form both real and virtual images depending on the position of the object. Real images are formed when the object is placed beyond the center of curvature, while virtual images are formed when the object is placed between the pole and the principal focus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Concave mirrors can form both real and virtual images depending on the position of the object. Convex mirrors, on the other hand, can only form virtual, erect, and diminished images regardless of the object's position. So inverted images can be real (formed by concave mirrors) or virtual (formed by both concave and convex mirrors).

questions.question_text: A ___ mirror curves outward and always forms virtual images.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror curves outward, which means its reflecting surface is shaped like the outer surface of a sphere. Because of this, convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images. This is why the correct answer for this question is 'convex'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is a single word. The incorrect answer would be something like 'a concave mirror', but that is not correct because concave mirrors can form real or virtual images, while convex mirrors always form virtual images.

questions.question_text: The distance from the pole to the focus is called the ___ length.
questions.explanation_correct: The distance from the pole to the focus of a spherical mirror is called the focal length. This is because the focus is the point where light rays reflected by the mirror converge, and the distance from the pole to this point is the focal length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'focal' length. The focal length is the distance from the pole (the center of the mirror) to the principal focus, which is the point where light rays reflected by the mirror converge. This is an important property of spherical mirrors and is denoted by the symbol 'f'.

questions.question_text: Images that cannot be obtained on a screen are called ___ images.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'virtual' because images that cannot be formed on a screen are called virtual images. Convex mirrors and some concave mirror positions always form virtual images, meaning the light rays don't actually intersect to form a real image that can be projected onto a screen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'virtual'. The incorrect answer would be 'real', but real images can be formed on a screen, unlike virtual images. Virtual images are formed when the light rays appear to be coming from a point, but they don't actually intersect to form a real image that can be projected onto a surface.

questions.question_text: If R = 30 cm, then f = ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: If the radius of curvature (R) of a spherical mirror is 30 cm, then the focal length (f) of the mirror is half of the radius, which is 15 cm. This is because the formula for the focal length of a spherical mirror is f = R/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 15. However, the incorrect answer would be to say that the focal length (f) is 30 cm. This is wrong because the focal length is always half the radius of curvature (R). Since R is given as 30 cm, the correct focal length (f) should be 15 cm, which is R/2.

questions.question_text: ___ mirrors are used by dentists to see enlarged images of teeth.
questions.explanation_correct: Concave mirrors are used by dentists to see enlarged images of teeth because the concave curved surface of the mirror allows it to magnify the image. The concave mirror forms a real, enlarged image of the teeth that the dentist can easily see and examine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are not used by dentists to see enlarged images of teeth. Convex mirrors form virtual, diminished images that appear smaller than the actual object. Concave mirrors, on the other hand, form real, enlarged images that are better suited for the dentist to closely examine the patient's teeth.

questions.question_text: An image formed at infinity by a concave mirror is formed when the object is at the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The image formed at infinity by a concave mirror is formed when the object is at the focus (principal focus) of the mirror. This is because the rays from an object at the focus are parallel when they reflect off the concave mirror, forming an image at infinity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'focus'. The image formed at infinity by a concave mirror is not formed when the object is at the center of curvature (C) or the pole (P) of the mirror. Instead, it is formed when the object is placed at the focus (F) of the mirror, where the reflected rays are parallel.

questions.question_text: Concave mirrors ___ light rays to a focus.
questions.explanation_correct: Concave mirrors converge light rays to a focus because the curved reflecting surface bends the light inwards, causing the rays to meet at a single point known as the principal focus. This is a key property of concave mirrors that allows them to be used in devices like torches and shaving mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'converge'. Concave mirrors do not diverge or scatter light rays. Instead, the curved reflecting surface of a concave mirror bends the light inwards, causing the rays to converge or meet at a single point called the principal focus. This focusing ability is the key feature that makes concave mirrors useful in various applications.

questions.question_text: Magnification is the ratio of image height to ___ height.
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification of a spherical mirror is the ratio of the image height to the object height. This is because the magnification tells us how much bigger or smaller the image appears compared to the actual object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnification of a spherical mirror is not the ratio of image height to mirror height. The correct answer is that magnification is the ratio of image height to object height. This is because the magnification formula compares the size of the image to the size of the actual object, not the size of the mirror itself.

questions.question_text: For a concave mirror, arrange object positions by increasing image size:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Object at infinity, Object at C, Object between P and F. As the object moves closer to the mirror, the image size increases. An object at infinity forms the smallest image, an object at the center of curvature (C) forms an image of the same size, and an object between the pole (P) and the focal point (F) forms the largest image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Object between P and F, Object at C, Object at infinity. This is wrong because as the object moves closer to the mirror, the image size increases. An object between P and F forms the largest image, an object at C forms an image of the same size, and an object at infinity forms the smallest image.

questions.question_text: Arrange by increasing distance from the mirror (for concave):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from smallest to largest distance from the mirror is Pole, Focus, Center of curvature. The pole is the center of the mirror surface, the focus is where light rays converge, and the center of curvature is the center of the sphere that the mirror is part of, so it is the farthest from the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Center of curvature, Pole, Focus. This is wrong because the center of curvature is the farthest from the mirror, followed by the pole which is the center of the mirror, and then the focus which is where light rays converge and is closest to the mirror.

questions.question_text: Arrange the image characteristics as object moves from beyond C to between P and F in a concave mirror:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Image at F (highly diminished), Image at C (same size), Image virtual and magnified behind mirror. As the object moves from beyond C to between P and F, the image moves from real and inverted at C, to highly diminished and real at F, and finally to virtual and magnified behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to have the virtual and magnified image between P and F first, before the image at C. This is not correct because as the object moves closer to the mirror, the image changes from virtual and magnified to real and same size at C, and then to real and diminished at F.

questions.question_text: Arrange by typical field of view (narrowest to widest):
questions.explanation_correct: The typical field of view is narrowest for a concave mirror, wider for a plane mirror, and widest for a convex mirror. This is because a concave mirror has a smaller field of view as it reflects light from a smaller area, while a convex mirror has a larger field of view as it reflects light from a wider area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order from narrowest to widest field of view is not correct. A concave mirror has the narrowest field of view because it reflects light from a smaller area, a plane mirror has a wider field of view, and a convex mirror has the widest field of view as it reflects light from a larger area. This is because the curved surface of a convex mirror allows it to capture a wider angle of view compared to a flat plane mirror or a concave mirror.

questions.question_text: How does a concave mirror differ from a convex mirror in the direction of its reflecting surface?

options.text: Concave curves outward, convex curves inward
Concave curves inward, convex curves outward
Both curve inward but at different angles
Both curve outward but convex curves more sharply

questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curving inward (like the inside of a hollow sphere), while a convex mirror has its reflecting surface curving outward (like the outside of a sphere). This fundamental difference in curvature direction is what distinguishes the two types of spherical mirrors and determines how they form images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the directions — it is the concave mirror that curves inward, not outward. Options C and D are incorrect because the two types of mirrors curve in opposite directions, not the same direction. The key distinction is that concave means 'curving inward' and convex means 'curving outward'.

questions.question_text: How does the nature of the image formed by a concave mirror differ from that of a convex mirror when the object is far away?

options.text: Concave forms a virtual image; convex forms a real image
Concave forms a real, inverted image; convex forms a virtual, erect image
Both form real, inverted images of different sizes
Both form virtual, erect images of different sizes

questions.explanation_correct: When an object is far away, a concave mirror forms a real, inverted, and diminished image (between F and C), because the reflected rays actually converge in front of the mirror. A convex mirror, on the other hand, always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image regardless of object distance, because the reflected rays diverge and only appear to meet behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the image types — concave mirrors form real images for distant objects, not virtual ones. Options C and D are incorrect because only concave mirrors form real images for distant objects; convex mirrors always form virtual images. The key difference is that concave mirrors converge light (producing real images) while convex mirrors diverge light (producing virtual images).

questions.question_text: How does the position of the focus differ in a concave mirror compared to a convex mirror?

options.text: Concave has focus behind the mirror; convex has focus in front
Concave has focus in front of the mirror (real); convex has focus behind the mirror (virtual)
Both have focus in front of the mirror
Both have focus behind the mirror

questions.explanation_correct: In a concave mirror, parallel rays actually converge at the focus, which lies in front of the reflecting surface — this is a real focus. In a convex mirror, parallel rays diverge after reflection and only appear to come from a point behind the mirror — this is a virtual focus. This difference in focus position is directly related to the curvature of each mirror type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the positions — it is the concave mirror that has its focus in front, not behind. Options C and D are wrong because the two mirror types have their focal points on opposite sides of the reflecting surface. Concave mirrors converge light to a real focus in front, while convex mirrors appear to diverge light from a virtual focus behind the mirror.

questions.question_text: How does the image seen in a shaving mirror differ from the image seen in a vehicle rear-view mirror?

options.text: Shaving mirror image is diminished; rear-view mirror image is magnified
Shaving mirror image is magnified and erect; rear-view mirror image is diminished and erect
Both show magnified images but of different sizes
Shaving mirror image is inverted; rear-view mirror image is erect

questions.explanation_correct: A shaving mirror is a concave mirror, and when the face is held close (between P and F), it produces a virtual, erect, and magnified image — allowing fine details to be seen clearly. A vehicle rear-view mirror is a convex mirror, which always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image — allowing a wider field of view behind the vehicle. Both images are erect, but they differ in magnification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the magnification — a shaving mirror (concave) magnifies, while a rear-view mirror (convex) diminishes. Option C is wrong because convex rear-view mirrors always produce diminished images, not magnified ones. Option D is incorrect because the shaving mirror image is erect (when used properly between P and F), not inverted.

questions.question_text: How does the image of an object placed at C of a concave mirror differ from the image when the object is placed between F and C?

options.text: At C the image is same size; between F and C the image is magnified — both are real and inverted
At C the image is magnified; between F and C the image is diminished
At C the image is virtual; between F and C the image is real
At C the image is inverted; between F and C the image is erect

questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at the center of curvature (C), the image forms at C itself and is the same size as the object, real, and inverted. When the object is placed between F and C, the image forms beyond C and is magnified, real, and inverted. In both cases the image is real and inverted, but the key difference is in size — same size at C versus magnified between F and C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the size relationship — the image is same size at C and magnified between F and C, not the other way around. Option C is wrong because images at both positions are real, not virtual. Option D is incorrect because the image is inverted at both positions. The only difference is in the relative size of the image.

questions.question_text: A mirror converges parallel light rays to a single point in front of it. What type of mirror is this?
questions.explanation_correct: A mirror that converges parallel light rays to a single point in front of it is a concave mirror. The inward-curving reflecting surface of a concave mirror causes parallel rays to reflect and meet at the principal focus, which lies in front of the mirror. This converging property is why concave mirrors are also called converging mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex mirror diverges parallel rays rather than converging them — it cannot bring light to a single point. A plane mirror reflects parallel rays as parallel rays — it neither converges nor diverges them. A cylindrical mirror focuses light along a line, not to a single point. Only a concave mirror has the ability to converge parallel light rays to a focal point.

questions.question_text: A mirror always produces images that are virtual, erect, and smaller than the object regardless of where the object is placed. What type of mirror is this?
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror always forms virtual, erect, and diminished images no matter where the object is placed. This is because the outward curvature of a convex mirror causes reflected rays to diverge, so they never actually meet — the image appears to form behind the mirror and is always smaller than the object. No other mirror type consistently produces this combination of image characteristics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror can form both real and virtual images depending on object position — it does not always produce diminished images. A plane mirror forms virtual, erect images but they are the same size as the object, not smaller. The property of always forming virtual, erect, and diminished images is unique to convex mirrors.

questions.question_text: A mirror is used at a sharp turn on a mountain road so that drivers can see vehicles coming from the other side. What type of mirror is this?
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror is used at sharp turns on mountain roads because it provides a wider field of view. Its outward-curving surface allows drivers to see vehicles approaching from the other side of the bend, even though the images appear smaller. The wide-angle view provided by convex mirrors is essential for safety at blind curves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror would not be suitable because it has a narrow field of view and can form inverted images, which would confuse drivers. A plane mirror has a limited field of view compared to a convex mirror. The wide field of view needed at road bends is best provided by a convex mirror, which is why they are commonly installed at sharp turns.

questions.question_text: An image is formed that is real, inverted, and magnified. The image forms beyond the center of curvature. Identify the object position for a concave mirror.
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed between the focus (F) and center of curvature (C) of a concave mirror, the image is formed beyond C. This image is real (formed by actual convergence of reflected rays), inverted (upside down), and magnified (larger than the object). This is the only object position that gives an image with all three of these characteristics at this location.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An object at infinity forms a highly diminished image at the focus, not a magnified one beyond C. An object at C forms an image at C that is the same size, not magnified. An object between P and F forms a virtual, erect, and magnified image behind the mirror, not a real one beyond C. Only when the object is between F and C does the concave mirror produce a real, inverted, magnified image beyond C.

questions.question_text: Riya goes to a dentist for a check-up. The dentist holds a small mirror inside her mouth close to her teeth and sees a large, clear image of each tooth. What type of mirror is the dentist using, and why does the image appear magnified?

options.text: Convex mirror — it magnifies objects placed close to it
Concave mirror — the tooth is between P and F, so the image is virtual, erect, and magnified
Plane mirror — it shows the same size image at close range
Concave mirror — the tooth is beyond C, so the image is real and magnified

questions.explanation_correct: Dentists use concave mirrors. When the tooth is positioned very close to the mirror — between the pole (P) and the focus (F) — the concave mirror produces a virtual, erect, and magnified image. This allows the dentist to see an enlarged view of the teeth for detailed examination. The mirror works because at this close range, reflected rays diverge and appear to come from a larger image behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because convex mirrors always form diminished images, not magnified ones. Option C is wrong because plane mirrors show same-size images, which would not help a dentist see fine details. Option D gives the wrong reason — an object beyond C would form a diminished image, not a magnified one. The correct explanation is that the tooth is between P and F of a concave mirror.

questions.question_text: Amit is doing an experiment in his school physics lab. He places a candle 25 cm in front of a concave mirror whose focal length is 15 cm. He notices that the image of the candle flame is inverted and larger than the real flame. Where should Amit place a screen to capture this image?

options.text: At the focus of the mirror
Between the focus and the center of curvature

questions.explanation_correct: The focal length is 15 cm, so the center of curvature is at R = 2f = 30 cm. The candle at 25 cm is between F (15 cm) and C (30 cm). For a concave mirror, when the object is between F and C, the image forms beyond C, is real, inverted, and magnified. This matches what Amit observes — an inverted, larger image. So Amit should place the screen beyond C (beyond 30 cm from the mirror) to capture the image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong — the image at the focus forms only when the object is at infinity. Option B is wrong — the image between F and C forms when the object is beyond C, and that image would be diminished. Option D is wrong — a screen behind the mirror cannot capture a real image since real images form in front of the mirror. The correct position is beyond C.

questions.question_text: Priya is sitting in her father's car at a traffic signal. She looks at the side mirror and notices that the auto-rickshaw behind them appears smaller than its actual size but she can see a wide area of the road behind. What type of mirror is used as the side mirror, and what property makes it suitable?

options.text: Concave mirror — it converges light to show a wider field of view
Convex mirror — it forms diminished, erect images and provides a wider field of view
Plane mirror — it shows true-size images with a wide field of view
Convex mirror — it forms magnified images to see distant objects clearly

questions.explanation_correct: Vehicle side mirrors use convex mirrors. Priya sees the auto-rickshaw smaller than actual size because convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images. The key advantage is the wider field of view — the outward-curving surface captures light from a broader area, allowing the driver to see more of the road behind. This trade-off between image size and viewing area makes convex mirrors ideal for vehicle mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because concave mirrors actually narrow the field of view due to their converging nature. Option C is wrong because plane mirrors show true-size images but have a narrower field of view than convex mirrors. Option D incorrectly states that convex mirrors magnify — they always diminish the image. The correct answer is B, as convex mirrors specifically provide wide-angle, diminished views.

questions.question_text: Arjun finds a spherical mirror in the school lab. He measures the distance from the pole to the center of curvature and finds it to be 36 cm. His teacher asks him to calculate the focal length. What is the focal length of this mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: The distance from the pole to the center of curvature is the radius of curvature (R), which is 36 cm. Using the relationship R = 2f, the focal length f = R/2 = 36/2 = 18 cm. Arjun should report the focal length as 18 cm. This relationship holds for all spherical mirrors — the focal length is always half the radius of curvature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (72 cm) incorrectly doubles the radius instead of halving it. Option B (36 cm) confuses the radius of curvature with the focal length — they are not equal. Option D (12 cm) incorrectly divides by 3 instead of 2. The formula f = R/2 gives f = 36/2 = 18 cm.

questions.question_text: Meera holds a spoon with the concave (inner) side facing her at arm's length. She notices her image is upside down. She then slowly brings the spoon closer to her face, and at one point the image suddenly flips to become upright and larger. What happened?

options.text: The spoon changed from concave to convex as she moved it
Her face crossed the focal point — beyond F the image is real and inverted, but between P and F it becomes virtual, erect, and magnified
The image flipped because she crossed the center of curvature
The image always stays inverted in a concave surface; she imagined the flip

questions.explanation_correct: When Meera held the spoon far away, her face was beyond the focus (F) of the concave surface, so the image was real, inverted, and diminished. As she brought the spoon closer, her face passed through the focal point. Once her face was between the pole (P) and focus (F), the concave surface formed a virtual, erect, and magnified image. This transition at the focal point is a well-known property of concave mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong — the spoon shape does not change; only the distance between the face and the reflective surface changes. Option C is wrong — the image flip happens at the focus (F), not at the center of curvature (C). At C, the image changes from magnified to same-size, not from inverted to erect. Option D is wrong — concave mirrors can form both inverted and erect images depending on object distance.

questions.question_text: A student claims that concave mirrors can only form real images. Which of the following is actually true about concave mirrors?

options.text: Concave mirrors always form real and inverted images
Concave mirrors form a virtual, erect, and magnified image when the object is between the pole and focus
Concave mirrors form virtual images only when the object is at the center of curvature
Concave mirrors cannot form virtual images under any circumstance

questions.explanation_correct: The student's claim is incorrect. While concave mirrors do form real images for most object positions (at C, between F and C, beyond C, and at infinity), there is one important exception: when the object is placed between the pole (P) and the focus (F), a concave mirror forms a virtual, erect, and magnified image. This is exactly how concave mirrors are used as shaving mirrors and dentist mirrors — the object is held very close to the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and D repeat the misconception that concave mirrors can only form real images — this is false. Option C places the exception at the wrong position; at the center of curvature, the image is real and same-sized. The virtual image occurs specifically when the object is between P and F, making option B the only correct statement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following seems like it should use a convex mirror but actually uses a concave mirror?

options.text: Shop security mirror on the ceiling
Mirror at a blind turn on a road

questions.explanation_correct: A torch reflector uses a concave mirror, not a convex mirror. Students often associate any mirror in a practical device with convex mirrors because convex mirrors are commonly discussed in everyday applications. However, a torch needs to produce a strong, parallel beam of light, which requires a concave mirror with the bulb at its focus. The concave mirror converges the diverging light from the bulb into a focused beam. The other three options (rear-view mirror, security mirror, road bend mirror) all genuinely use convex mirrors for their wide field of view.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vehicle rear-view mirrors (A), shop security mirrors (C), and blind-turn road mirrors (D) all correctly use convex mirrors because they need a wide field of view. The torch reflector (B) is the exception — it uses a concave mirror because the goal is to focus light into a parallel beam, not to see a wide area. The bulb is placed at the focus of the concave mirror so that reflected rays travel in parallel.

questions.question_text: A student says: 'Since convex mirrors always form virtual images, they are useless for practical purposes.' Which of the following is a real-world use that proves this statement wrong?

options.text: Convex mirrors are used in solar furnaces to concentrate sunlight
Convex mirrors are used in vehicle side mirrors because their wide field of view improves safety
Convex mirrors are used in projectors to enlarge images on a screen
Convex mirrors are used in telescopes to magnify distant stars

questions.explanation_correct: The student's claim is wrong. Even though convex mirrors form only virtual, erect, and diminished images, this property is extremely useful for vehicle side mirrors. The diminished image allows a larger area to be visible in a small mirror, giving drivers a wider field of view of the road behind them. This proves that forming virtual images does not make a mirror 'useless' — it simply means the mirror is suited for different purposes than concave mirrors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because solar furnaces use concave mirrors to concentrate sunlight, not convex mirrors. Option C is wrong because projectors use concave mirrors or lenses, not convex mirrors. Option D is wrong because telescopes use concave mirrors or lenses to collect and focus light. Only option B correctly identifies a real practical use of convex mirrors — as vehicle side mirrors for their wide field of view.

questions.question_text: Why are concave mirrors used in headlights of vehicles instead of convex mirrors?

options.text: Because concave mirrors are cheaper to manufacture than convex mirrors
Because concave mirrors reflect the light from a bulb at the focus as a powerful parallel beam
Because concave mirrors form virtual images of the road ahead
Because concave mirrors provide a wider field of view for the driver

questions.explanation_correct: Concave mirrors are used in headlights because when the bulb is placed at the principal focus of the concave mirror, the diverging light rays from the bulb are reflected as a strong, parallel beam of light that travels far ahead. This focused beam illuminates the road over long distances. A convex mirror would scatter the light in all directions, producing a weak, spread-out beam that would not effectively light the road.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the choice of mirror is based on optical properties, not cost. Option C is wrong because the headlight mirror is not meant to form images of the road — its purpose is to redirect the bulb's light into a parallel beam. Option D is wrong because a wider field of view is a property of convex mirrors used in rear-view mirrors, not headlights. The correct reason is the concave mirror's ability to produce a parallel beam from a point source at its focus.

questions.question_text: Why does a convex mirror always form a virtual image and never a real image?

options.text: Because convex mirrors are too small to form real images
Because the reflected rays from a convex mirror always diverge and never actually meet in front of the mirror
Because convex mirrors absorb some light, preventing real image formation
Because the focus of a convex mirror is too far away for rays to converge

questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror's outward-curving surface causes all reflected rays to diverge (spread apart) after reflection. Since the reflected rays never actually converge at a point in front of the mirror, no real image can be formed. The rays only appear to come from a point behind the mirror when extended backwards — this is why the image is always virtual. A real image requires actual convergence of light rays, which a convex mirror's geometry physically prevents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong — the size of the mirror does not determine whether it forms real or virtual images; the curvature direction does. Option C is wrong — convex mirrors reflect light just as well as concave mirrors; they do not absorb light differently. Option D is wrong — the focus of a convex mirror is virtual (behind the mirror), not far away. The fundamental reason is the divergence of reflected rays due to the outward curvature.

questions.question_text: Why does a ray of light passing through the center of curvature of a concave mirror retrace its path after reflection?

options.text: Because the ray strikes the mirror surface at an angle equal to the focal length
Because the ray hits the mirror along the normal (perpendicular to the surface), so the angle of incidence is zero
Because the center of curvature has special reflective properties
Because the mirror surface is flat at the center of curvature

questions.explanation_correct: A ray passing through the center of curvature (C) hits the mirror surface along the radius of the sphere. Since the normal to any point on a sphere passes through its center, this ray is perpendicular to the mirror surface — meaning the angle of incidence is zero. By the law of reflection (angle of reflection equals angle of incidence), the angle of reflection is also zero, so the ray reflects straight back along its original path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because focal length is a distance measurement, not an angle, and is not directly relevant here. Option C is wrong because the center of curvature has no special reflective properties — it is simply the geometric center of the sphere. Option D is wrong because the mirror surface is curved at every point, not flat. The correct reason is that the ray travels along the normal (radius) to the mirror surface, making the angle of incidence zero.
